instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message:
- No liquid damage
- Fixed short on PP3V3S5 FET.
- PPVIN = 20v
- Several short (?0.1 ohm) on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (PMIC) rails
** <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>
** <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> 
** <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G_REG</SIGNAL>

Lifted coils for the last 2 and both have the short on the load side a.k.a. CPU/PCH. Of course, the CPU could be shorted. Would it also be possible there's one common short somewhere, causing these rails to short through the CPU? Any suggestions on how to proceed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message:
I have NEVER saw multiple short on CPU (or other common component), caused by other different things!

Very easy to discard.
Choose the higher voltage and lower short value from al these power rails.
Inject volyage there and check if CPU heats...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Just tested and both <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> cause the CPU to heat when voltage is injected. I also noticed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (PMIC) getting warm. Would it be wise to try change this, or should I assume it's the CPU at this point. This would be 3 in a row for me (2 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>'s though, these don't count :))

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: I wouldn't waste time with this. These boards (00875 and 00840) are awful. Almost every one I see in my shop has a shorted CPU or does not post from a dead CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead
threads.message: Ok, good to know. Not really up to speed on repairability of these "new" types. Thanks for your help guys, this is a no-fix.
